author: djrtwo
content:
thanks! glad to see you digging in here :)

I wrote up a response
https://notes.ethereum.org/@djrtwo/rkKoPYjHP

The real trick is figure out how to condition the following on an epoch number in the context of your language and architecture:
* upgrading/modifying types
* irregular state change
* conditional logic changes

I highly recommend taking a look at how this is done in a couple of eth1 clients (block height instead of epoch # in those). We're fortunate to have a bunch of language examples and different engineering approaches to learn from.

author: prestonvanloon
content:
Thanks for the response, I think I have more questions now than before :)

Slashing is something I had not considered. I assumed that the "fork" field in the state would be used for any and all upgrades that required some consensus changing logic. However, with slashing being a factor, we can only realistically update this value of few times per year (depends on weak subjectivity sync period) or risk old slashing events becoming unacceptable. Do you see this as a concern? 

Perhaps my assumption is incorrect. Is fork field in the state meant to be used as the universal "current fork" in the state of eth2?
